Chromium catalysts, prepared with different chromium contents, supports and precursor compounds, were characterized by O2 and CO chemisorption, in order to quantify the Cr3+ and Cr2+ sites, respectively. The distribution of chromium species, which depends on the preparation parameters, was related to the catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation and polymerization reactions. Chromium catalysts, prepared with different chromium contents, supports and precursor compounds, were characterized by O2 and CO chemisorption, in order to quantify the Cr3+ and Cr2+ sites, active species to dehydrogenation and ethylene polymerization reactions. Both probe molecules, O2 and CO, showed to be selective to the chromium active species, Cr3+ and Cr2+, respectively, and a valid method to quantify these sites. Distinct chromium species, Cr6+, amorphous Cr3+, crystalline Cr3+ and Cr2+, were characterized by XRD, DRS, TPR, FT-IR and DRIFTS in the calcined and reduced catalysts. The distribution of chromium species, which depends on the content, precursor compound and support, was related to the catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation and polymerization reactions. The catalytic activity to cyclohexane dehydrogenation depends on the dispersion of amorphous Cr3+ species. The activity in the ethylene polymerization is related to the amount of CrA 2+ and CrB 2+ species. Both sites showed similar activities. Keywords Cr/SiO2 Cr/Al2O3 Chemisorption XRD DRS FT-IR DRIFTS TPR 1 Introduction Chromium catalysts supported on silica and on alumina have industrial application in ethylene polymerization and dehydrogenation reactions [1–5]. The active sites for these reactions are Cr2+ [6–9] and Cr3+ [10–12], respectively. The chromium catalysts for ethylene polymerization, Phillips-type, are prepared by impregnation of an inorganic precursor on silica of high specific surface and volume of pores, yielding catalysts with 1wt.% or less chromium content. The literature [13–16] suggests that, independently of the precursor, there is not difference in the oxidation state of the chromium with low Cr content, after calcination, being observed mainly Cr6+. Otherwise, in previous works [17,18], we showed that the chromium content and the precursor compound affected largely the chromium species distribution in their calcined and reduced forms. Chromium supported catalysts are used in the ethane, propane, n-butane and isobutane dehydrogenations to the corresponding olefins, in the temperature range of 623–773K and atmospheric pressure, with high selectivity to alkenes [19]. One of the dehydrogenation reactions of largest commercial interest is the dehydrogenation of isobutane to yield isobutene, which is intermediary for methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) production. MTBE is added to gasoline to improve the octane number, yielding cleaner burning fuel [20], but the contamination of drinking water and groundwater by MTBE is causing its elimination as a gasoline additive [21]. However, an important amount of the isobutene is used to produce butyl rubber, polyisobutylene and other specialities [22]. Besides, the oxidative and non-oxidative isobutane dehydrogenation with chromium catalysts still deserve interest in the literature as a model reaction [23–25]. Cr/Al2O3 catalysts have been used industrially in dehydrogenation reactions. These catalysts are prepared by impregnation of a chromium compound, usually nitrate, and resulting catalysts with chromium loading in the range of 3–13wt.% Cr [3]. The chromium is anchored on alumina through the basic and neutral hydroxyls, observed by infrared spectroscopy at 3775 and 3730cm−1 [19]. The additions of potassium to reduce cracking reactions [3] and other supports, such as zirconia [26], have also been studied. Several factors have influence in the catalytic activity of the chromium catalysts, as the oxidation state, the structure (amorphous or crystalline, chromates or dichromates) and the interaction of the chromium species with the support. These variations depend on the metallic content, the precursor compound of chromium, the support characteristics and calcination conditions [2,3]. In the calcined state, the presence of Cr6+, with different interactions with the support, and crystalline or amorphous Cr3+ have been studied by influencing in the formation of active species in the polymerization and dehydrogenation reactions [1–3,12–14,17–19]. The literature reports that the active site in the dehydrogenation is the Cr3+ species coordinated to the hydroxyls, coordinativelly unsaturated [10–12]. This species can be obtained by reduction of the calcined sample with H2 at 773K. On the other hand, the active site of chromium for ethylene polymerization was reported to be the Cr2+ [2,6–9,27]. These sites can be obtained by reduction of the calcined sample with carbon monoxide at 623K [28]. The reduction with carbon monoxide converts Cr6+ to Cr2+, while with H2 only Cr3+ is obtained. Moreover, the Cr3+ originally present is not reduced [17]. The characterization of the chromium sites of the calcined and reduced states has been studied by using different spectroscopic techniques, like XPS, DRS and FT-IR [2,8,17,29–31]. However, the presence of different surface chromium species hinders the interpretation of the spectra. Particularly, in the analysis of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), the photoreduction of the Cr6+ species, induced by the exposition to the X-rays, requires the use of procedures to minimize this effect in order to validate the results [29–31]. The application of adsorption techniques of probe molecules, that allows to quantify the chromium sites, is not very explored and the methodology is not consolidated [12,18,32,33]. The literature reports the use of the chemisorption of O2 at low temperatures to quantify the Cr3+ sites in the bulk or supported Cr2O3 [12,32]. Even so, the selectivity of the chemisorption of O2 to the amorphous sites Cr3+ requires more detailed studies. On the other hand, the Cr2+ is reported as the active site for ethylene polymerization in Cr/SiO2 catalysts, being characterized by adsorption of carbon monoxide at room temperature [33], followed by infrared spectroscopy analysis. The Cr2+ sites are divided in CrA 2+, CrB 2+ and CrC 2+ species [6,7,27], in decreasing order of interaction with the hydroxyls groups on the surface of the support, according to the schematic representation of Kim and Woo [27], as showed in Fig. 1 . The CrA 2+ and CrB 2+ species are reported to be active in the polymerization, being CrA 2+ the most active [7,8]. Both species adsorb carbon monoxide at 298K, while the CrC 2+ does not. In a previous work [18], we showed that catalysts with similar CrA 2+ amount presented different activities in the ethylene polymerization. Our results suggested that not only CrA 2+, but also CrB 2+ sites have activity in the polymerization. The main problem in the identification of the Cr2+ sites is its oxidation when in contact with very low concentration (ppm) of oxygen and/or water [34]. Thus, the characterization and the use of these catalysts in the polymerization require the attainment and maintenance of the Cr2+ species during the process. Besides, just a small amount of the Cr2+ sites can be considered active to the polymerization (less than 1wt.% Cr) [35,36]. Therefore, the identification and quantification of these species are important to explain the behavior of chromium catalysts in the ethylene polymerization. The objective of this work was to study the chemisorption of O2 and CO to quantify the active sites of chromium catalysts and to evaluate the catalytic activity in the cyclohexane dehydrogenation and in the ethylene polymerization in the light of the chromium species characterization. The dehydrogenation reaction was studied with chromium catalysts prepared on silica and on alumina by varying the chromium content. The polymerization reaction was carried out with chromium catalysts prepared with different precursors supported on silica, resulting 1wt.% Cr. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS), temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of H2 and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS). The active sites for dehydrogenation and polymerization reactions were quantified by O2 and CO chemisorption, after reduction with H2 or CO, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts The catalysts were prepared by impregnation of aqueous solutions (15ml/g support) with different chromium contents and precursors added to the γ-Al2O3 (Engelhard HARSHAW AL3916P, surface area=191m2/g and pore volume=0.46cm3/g) and SiO2 supports (Davison GRACE 955, surface area=299m2/g and pore volume=1.6cm3/g). The ethylene polymerization was investigated with Cr/SiO2 catalysts prepared with different chromium precursors. In the preparation of these Cr/SiO2 catalysts, chromium acetate(II), chromium chloride(II), chromium oxide(VI), all obtained from Aldrich (99.9% purity), and bis(triphenylsilyl)chromate, prepared according to Baker and Carrick [37], were used, resulting samples with 1wt.% Cr. The bis(triphenylsilyl)chromate salt was solubilized in hexane (Merck) prior to the catalyst preparation. Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al2O3 catalysts prepared with different chromium contents were studied in the cyclohexane dehydrogenation. Cr/SiO2 catalysts were prepared using chromium(III) nitrate (Merck) resulting samples with 1.5, 3 and 5wt.% Cr. In the preparation of the Cr/Al2O3 catalysts, an aqueous solution of chromium(III) nitrate (Merck) was also used, with contents in the range of 1.5–9wt.% Cr. The catalysts were calcined at 773–823K for 4h under dry air flow. Physical mixtures were also prepared mixing by careful grinding CrO3 or Cr2O3 (Aldrich, 99.9%) with silica in an agate mortar, resulting the content of 3wt.% Cr, and CrO3 with alumina, in the contents of 2 and 13wt.% Cr. 2.2 Characterization techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out with the calcined samples, employing a Rigaku Miniflex difractometer (voltage: 30kV and current: 15mA), equipped with a copper tube (λ=1.5417Å) and a graphite monochromator, operated in the step-scan mode 0.05° 2θ per step and counting for 2s per step. Infrared spectroscopy experiments were performed on a FT-IR Perkin-Elmer 2000 spectrometer with a resolution of 4cm−1, in order to observe the change of the hydroxyls region of silica and alumina because of the interaction with chromium. Self supported wafers (∼10mg/cm2) were pretreated in situ in a cell equipped with CaF2 window. The samples were submitted to vacuum at 773K for 1h before the analyses. FT-IR spectra were obtained rationing the experimental spectra by the background. The Cr/SiO2 catalysts with 1wt.% Cr were also submitted to DRIFTS measurements on a NICOLET Magna IR 760 instrument with a diffuse reflectance accessory equiped with a vacuum cell from Spectratech. This analysis was carried out to observe the bands in the region at 2500–4000cm−1 ascribed to the interaction of Cr2+ species with the surface hydroxyls of the support, after reduction of the samples with carbon monoxide. The bands at 3725 and 3600cm−1, ascribed to CrB 2+ and CrC 2+ species, respectively, were monitored [27]. The DRIFTS cell was filled with approximately 22mg of the sample, and the following activation treatment was carried out in situ: helium flow (AGA, 99.999%) at 773K for 1h and reduction at 623K with a 5% CO/He flow (AGA, <2ppm O2, <3ppm H2O and <1ppm CO2) for 1h. The spectra were recorded with a resolution of 4cm−1 with a DTGS detector, and are presented as the subtraction of the reduced sample spectrum from the dried sample spectrum in the 4000–2500cm−1 region. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of H2 were performed in a Pyrex U-tube reactor with an on line thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The catalyst (0.5g) was dried at 773K for 1h with argon flow (AGA, 99.99%) and reduced from 298 to 1023K (10K/min) with 1.6% H2/Ar flow. The TCD, connected to a PC computer, allowed to study the reduction profiles of H2 with the temperature. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) analyses were done on a Varian Cary 5 UV-Vis-NIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Praying Mantis diffuse reflection device from Harrick. Spectra were taken in the calcined Cr/Al2O3 catalysts, in the range of 800–200nm, in order to observe the distinct Cr6+/Cr3+ species distribution. CrO3 and α-Cr2O3 spectra were used as references. The chemisorption analysis of carbon monoxide in the Cr/SiO2 catalysts was accomplished in an equipment ASAP 2000-C from Micromeritcs, after reduction of the samples with a mixture of 5% CO/He at 623K for 1h. The procedure was followed by chemisorption of carbon monoxide (static method) at 298K. The Cr/Al2O3 and Cr/SiO2 (prepared with chromium nitrate) catalysts were analyzed by chemisorption of O2 at 193K, after reduction with pure H2 at 773K for 1h. The chemisorption temperature was kept by using an isopropilic alcohol with liquid N2 mixture. The static chemisorption were obtained in the pressure range of 20–200mmHg. In each analysis, total and reversible adsorption isotherms were obtained. After reduction of the catalyst and vacuum at the reduction temperature, the total isotherm was obtained. Then, the sample was evacuated at the adsorption temperature and the second isotherm was determined, corresponding to the reversible isotherm. The irreversible chemisorption was obtained by the difference average between the total and reversible isotherms or by the extrapolation of the total isotherm to the null pressure. 2.3 Activity measurements The 1wt.% Cr/SiO2 catalysts (100mg), prepared with different chromium precursors, were submitted to the ethylene polymerization in a Büchi glasuster reactor (2l) at 358K and pressure of 22bar, using 1l of n-hexane (2–3ppm H2O) and triethyl-aluminum (molar TEA/Cr ratio=6.0). Initially, 1l of purified n-hexane and triethyl-aluminum (TEA), just enough to the elimination of residual humidity of the system, were added to the reactor. After that, the catalyst, previously reduced with CO at 623K, was carefully transferred to the reactor, using a glove bag with inert atmosphere. Then, purified ethylene (<4ppm H2O and <2ppm O2) was admitted up to the total pressure of 22bar. After 1h of reaction, the polyethylene was removed from the reactor, dried to elimination of the solvent and weighed for determination of the activity. The Cr/Al2O3 and Cr/SiO2 catalysts (0.5g), prepared with chromium nitrate and different contents, were studied in the cyclohexane dehydrogenation at 773K and at atmospheric pressure. The reactional mixture was obtained by passing H2 flow into a saturator maintained at 285K (W/F=0.016gmin/ml). In these conditions, diffusional effects are neglected. The tests were accomplished in differential reactor conditions, with conversions about 10%. The reduction pretreatments were identical to the used before the chemisorption analyses, in order to obtain the active sites for dehydrogenation and polymerization. 3 Results and discussion Chromium catalysts, prepared with different contents supported on silica and on alumina, were evaluated in the cyclohexane dehydrogenation. The ethylene polymerization was studied with 1wt.% Cr on silica, using distinct chromium compounds. The catalytic activity was associated with the chromium species characterization. Comparing the X-ray diffractograms of the catalysts with the one of the pure crystalline α-Cr2O3, the characteristic bands of this compound are observed in all the Cr/SiO2, but not in the catalysts prepared on alumina. This result indicates that the alumina hinders the formation of crystalline α-Cr2O3 phase or that it disperses the crystals of α-Cr2O3 turning them too small to be detected. Such results suggest a better dispersion of the chromium on alumina than on silica. Cavani et al. [1] observed the α-Cr2O3 phase with 5wt.% of chromium on alumina. However, the authors used a support composed by a mixture of three crystalline phases, which may turn easier the formation of the α-Cr2O3. The intensity of the characteristic bands of α-Cr2O3 increases with the chromium loading in the Cr/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 3). This crystalline phase was detected in the 1.5wt.% Cr on silica (1.5CrNSi), on the contrary of the reported by McDaniel and Welch [13], that just observed this species starting from 2.9wt.% Cr. However, other authors have observed lower values for the chromium monolayer on silica, in the range of 1.0–1.5wt.% Cr [19,38,39]. The FT-IR results are presented in the Figs. 4 and 5 . The consumption of the surface hydroxyls decreases as the chromium content increases. Such hydroxyls are the isolated ones in the silica (3740cm−1) and the basic and neutral ones in the alumina (3775 and 3730cm−1) [14,40–42]. In the Cr/SiO2 samples, a significant amount of isolated hydroxyls remains even for the greater chromium content. This result agrees with the work of Vuurman et. al. [19]. In the Cr/Al2O3 samples, the hydroxyls consumption is more evident. In the 9CrNAl catalyst, prepared with chromium(III) nitrate, the bands ascribed to the basic and neutral hydroxyls are almost indistinguishable. This result means an almost complete recovering of the surface of the support. The 13CrAlP6 sample, prepared with chromium oxide(VI), presented an unexpected result. Despite of being a physical mixture, its spectrum did not present the bands of the surface hydroxyls, showing interaction between the support and the CrO3, as well as a high covering degree. A spreading process must be occurring in this sample. Our hypothesis is based on low surface tension of the CrO3 and on the hygroscopic characteristic of this oxide. The CrO3 absorb water from the atmosphere, solubilizes in it and spreads in the surface of the support, as it occurs in the preparation of the catalysts. The 3CrSiP6 sample presented a similar result, with consumption of surface hydroxyls greater than would be expected for a physical mixture. Temperature programmed reduction with H2 was done to study the chromium-support interaction and to calculate the fraction of Cr6+ in the calcined catalysts. Consumption of H2 was not observed for α-Cr2O3. The physical mixtures of CrO3 with SiO2 and with Al2O3 presented H2 consumption corresponded to the theoretical reduction from Cr6+ to Cr3+, represented by the reaction 2CrO3+3H2→Cr2O3+3H2O. These results permitted to use the hypothesis that the final oxidation state of the chromium in the reduction conditions with H2 is Cr3+. Thus, it was obtained the fraction of Cr6+ in the calcined samples, taking into account the theoretical consumption of the reduction from Cr6+ to Cr3+ (29μmolH2/mgCr) and considering complete reduction of Cr6+. Table 2 presents the results of H2 consumption for the Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al2O3 catalysts, the temperature ascribed to the maximum consumption of H2 (T max) and the initial percentage of Cr6+. It is observed that the Cr/SiO2 catalysts presented a smaller H2 consumption than the theoretical value. This fact can be interpreted as being due to the existence of an initial fraction of Cr3+ in the catalysts or as a high interaction of the Cr6+ with the support, hindering its reduction to Cr3+. The XRD results confirm the first hypothesis, showing the existence of crystalline α-Cr2O3 phase in the three Cr/SiO2 catalysts after the calcination step, as reported in Fig. 3 and indicated in Table 2. It is also observed a similar H2 consumption for the 1.5CrNSi and 3CrNSi catalysts, with a marked decrease for the 5CrNSi catalyst. This behavior can be ascribed to the formation of a large fraction of Cr3+ in this catalyst and therefore reducing the H2 consumption. Fig. 6 exhibits the reduction profiles for the Cr/SiO2 catalysts. It is observed a main peak, in the temperature around 750K, ascribed to the reduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+. The temperatures of maximum consumption of H2 (T max) were similar, just increasing for the 5CrNSi catalyst. This fact can be interpreted in the same way of the consumption, relative to the formation of crystalline α-Cr2O3 phase, that would hinder the reduction of the Cr6+ species. Nevertheless, the catalysts also presented H2 consumption at lower temperature, around 650K. This behavior can be ascribed to the reduction of Cr6+ with different interactions with the support. According to Ellison et al. [43], reduction peaks in the region of 628–678K in Cr/SiO2 catalysts are ascribed to CrO3 clusters with smaller interaction with the support. Concerning the Cr/Al2O3 catalysts, the Table 2 shows that for the sample with the lowest chromium content the H2 consumption corresponds to the stoichometric value for the total reduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+. Thus, it was observed only Cr6+ in the 1.5CrNAl calcined sample. As the chromium content increases, the catalysts presented decrease in the H2 consumption. These results are in agreement with the diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) analyses, shown in Fig. 7 . The 1.5CrNAl and 3CrNAl catalysts presented bands at 260 and 380nm, ascribed to Cr6+, as shown by the CrO3 spectrum and also reported by Cavani et al. [1]. A shoulder at around 470nm is also shown, ascribed to Cr6+ in the chromate or dichromate arrangement in contact with the support. The increase of the chromium loading caused the appearance of a shoulder at 600nm in the 6CrNAl and 9CrNAl catalysts, ascribed to Cr3+ species, as shown in the α-Cr2O3 spectrum. Cavani et al. [1] also observed the initial formation of a fraction of Cr6+, followed by a fraction of Cr3+ in Cr/Al2O3 catalysts. In this study, the results indicated the initial formation of Cr6+ and, later, a growing formation of Cr3+, with increase of the chromium loading. Fig. 8 presents the reduction profiles obtained for the Cr/Al2O3 catalysts. Distinctly from the Cr/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 6), there is only one peak ascribed to the reduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+. Concerning the reduction temperature, it is observed that T max shifts to lower values as the chromium content increases. According to Cavani et al. [1], two Cr6+ species, the graftized and the soluble Cr6+, can be formed in Cr/Al2O3 catalysts by varying the chromium loading. The observed species in the lower contents is the graftized Cr6+, which presents greater interaction with the support than the soluble Cr6+, formed later. The interaction of the graftized Cr6+ with the support would difficult its reduction. As the chromium content increases, a larger fraction of the other species, the soluble Cr6+, easier to reduce, is formed. Comparing the supports, it is noticed that the catalysts on silica presented thoroughly smaller H2 consumption than on alumina, besides larger reduction temperature interval and higher maximum temperature (T max). Therefore, the alumina would be capable to stabilize a larger fraction of chromium in the Cr6+ oxidation state, or the support would present a smaller interaction with the Cr6+. Both arguments can explain the chromium reduction. These results show that the chromium reduction on silica is more difficult than on alumina, being consistent with the interpretation that the Cr6+ interacts more strongly with silica than with alumina. In order to verify the selectivity of the chemisorption of O2 to the amorphous Cr3+ species, active sites for dehydrogenation [10–12], previous tests were carried out with crystalline Cr3+ (α-Cr2O3) and CrO3 in physical mixtures. The tests were carried out after reduction treatment with flow of H2 at 773K. The physical mixture with the highest CrO3 loading (13CrAlP6) was used to verify the occurrence of O2 chemisorption in the Cr6+ sites. In this case, the pretreatment consisted only of drying the sample under He flow at 473K to avoid the reduction of the Cr6+. These tests are presented in the Table 3 . The results of the difference average among the total and reversible values of O2 (Q medium) of the supports and the physical mixtures (13CrAlP6 and 3CrSiP3) presented deviations in relation to the values obtained for the extrapolation of the total isotherm for null pressure (Q P 0 ). The isotherms obtained for the 3CrSiP3 physical mixture are presented in the Fig. 9(A) . It is noticed that the difference between the total and the reversible isotherms is not constant, increasing with the pressure, phenomenon ascribed to the physisorption [44,45]. Thus, the value of the amount of O2 chemisorbed corresponds to the extrapolation to null pressure. On the other hand, the isotherms for amorphous Cr3+ (2CrAlP6 physical mixture) presented similar values for the total isotherm at null pressure and the average of the difference among total and reversible isotherms, 4585 and 4464μmolO2/gCr, respectively (deviation around 3%). In this case, the discount of the reversible fraction of O2, guarantees the reliability of the irreversible amount. The same behavior was verified for all the catalysts, exemplified in the Fig. 9(B) for the 9CrNAl catalyst. With the results of Table 3, it was possible to confirm that the Cr6+ practically does not chemisorb O2 in comparison with the amorphous Cr3+. The crystalline Cr3+, bulk or in physical mixture with the support, chemisorb in small amount. However, α-Cr2O3 chemisorbs seven times more oxygen in physical mixture than in the bulk, 237 and 32μmolO2/gCr, respectively, ascribed to the dispersion process of the chromium with the support. The result found by Rama Rao et al. [12] for a bulk α-Cr2O3 (34μmolO2/gCr) was similar to that found in this study (32μmolO2/gCr). Nevertheless, in both cases the chemisorbed amount in the crystalline Cr3+ is small in comparison with the amorphous Cr3+. The chemisorbed amount in the amorphous Cr3+ (2CrAlP6) is about 20 times greater than for α-Cr2O3 in physical mixture, what means that O2 chemisorption occurs predominantly in the amorphous Cr3+. The Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al2O3 catalysts were analyzed by O2 chemisorption with the aim of study the effects of the chromium content and of the support in the active sites for dehydrogenation reaction. The Fig. 10 shows that both Cr/Al2O3 and Cr/SiO2 catalysts presented a decrease of the O2 chemisorption as the chromium content increases. It is also observed that the physical mixtures of CrO3 on Al2O3 presented values of O2 chemisorption with the same tendency of the catalysts, depending on the chromium content of the samples. This behavior is not the expected for simple physical mixtures. The result of the 2CrAlP6 sample is significant to analyze this subject. This sample presented a value for O2 chemisorption between 1.5CrNAl and 3CrNAl catalysts. As discussed for the FT-IR analysis of the 13CrAlP6 physical mixture, this result can also be ascribed to a spreading process driven by the extremely hygroscopic characteristic of CrO3. This spreading phenomenon can also be influenced by the characteristics of the support. As the CrO3 is an oxide with acidic character, it interacts with the basic hydroxyls of the alumina and this process is promoted by its low surface tension [46]. Table 4 presents the measurements of O2 chemisorption after the reduction treatment. The results show a decrease of the amount of O2 chemisorbed with the increase of the chromium content. The data were interpreted as an increase of the aggregation of the particles of chromium for higher contents. For Cr/SiO2 catalysts, another factor is that the decrease of the value of O2 chemisorption is consequence of the formation of the crystalline α-Cr2O3 phase, detected by XRD (Fig. 3), which does not chemisorb O2 and whose proportion would increase with the chromium content [1]. It is also observed that the results of O2 chemisorption for the samples on alumina were systematically greater than on silica, which suggests a better capacity of the alumina to disperse the active phase. This phenomenon is connected to the higher concentration of the surface hydroxyls of alumina in comparison to the silica. The concentration of the surface hydroxyls is estimated to be about 6.7 OH/nm2 in the silica and 12.6 OH/nm2 in the alumina at 373K [38,39]. The chemisorption results were coherent with the XRD analyses, which showed a crystalline α-Cr2O3 phase on silica whose intensity increased with the chromium content. This fact, once the crystalline Cr3+ does not chemisorb O2, provokes a decrease in the amount of O2 chemisorbed by chromium loading. On the other hand, crystalline phase was not found in the catalysts supported on alumina, Fig. 2, justifying that the results of chemisorption of the catalysts on alumina were larger than on silica. Based on those results, the O2 chemisorption analysis was considered consistent and a valid method to quantify the amorphous Cr3+ sites and, therefore, its results were compared with the catalytic tests. 3.1.2 Cyclohexane dehydrogenation Table 4 presents the results of cyclohexane dehydrogenation for the catalysts and physical mixtures. Benzene was the main product of the reaction, followed by traces of cyclohexene, as observed in the literature [47]. It was also verified that the α-Cr2O3 does not have activity for the dehydrogenation. The turnover number (TON) was calculated considering dissociative adsorption of O2 in the chromium sites, expressed by the O2/Cr=1:2 ratio [48]. The results show that the TON is not constant, increasing as the chromium content increases. Thus, for supported chromium oxide catalysts the reaction is not structure-insensitive, unlike the behavior observed for supported noble metals [49]. A 10-factor between the lowest and the highest activity for samples of chromium on alumina is observed. The increase in the chromium particles aggregation increases the activity of the amorphous Cr3+ sites. In the Cr/SiO2 catalysts, in spite of the detection of the α-Cr2O3 phase by XRD, the increase in the activity was also observed, ascribed to the amorphous Cr3+ aggregation. The physical mixtures presented a typical behavior of catalyst, with the activity shifting likewise the catalysts in function of the chromium content. A TON range of 20-times was obtained for the physical mixtures with 2 and 13wt.% Cr. However, the catalytic activity is mainly dependent of the dispersion of amorphous Cr3+ species. 3.2 Cr/SiO2 catalysts for polymerization 3.2.1 Characterization The catalysts, prepared with 1wt.% Cr using different precursors (Table 1), were characterized by XRD, CO chemisorption and DRIFTS. In these catalysts, the α-Cr2O3 phase was not observed by XRD, after the calcination step, as it was for the Cr/SiO2 catalysts prepared with chromium nitrate and loading of 1.5wt.% Cr and higher. In our previous work [17], a fraction of amorphous Cr2O3 was observed in DR spectra for the 1CrBSi and 1CrCSi catalysts, while 1CrASi and 1CrDSi presented only Cr6+ after calcination. Therefore, distinct fractions of Cr6+ and Cr3+ were identified in the calcined form, depending on the chromium compound. Preliminary tests with samples containing only Cr3+ or Cr6+ species in physical mixture were carried out in order to characterize the selectivity of CO chemisorption on Cr2+, active sites for ethylene polymerization. The physical mixture of Cr2O3 in SiO2 (3CrSiP3) did not present CO chemisorption, as well as the physical mixture of CrO3 in SiO2 (3CrSiP6), without previous reduction, and therefore presenting only Cr6+. These results show that the technique is selective to characterize Cr2+, since Cr6+ and Cr3+ species do not chemisorb CO. Table 5 presents the distribution of chromium species after reduction with CO. The Cr2+ species distribution was based on CO chemisorption and DRIFTS analyses in the hydroxyls region of the spectrum. The bands at 3745, 3725 and 3600cm−1 are ascribed to the isolated hydroxyls group [41], the CrB 2+ and CrC 2+ species interacting with the surface hydroxyls of the support, respectively [27]. In the calculation of the species distribution, we considered that the extinction coefficients of IR bands have the same order of magnitude and that the adsorption stoichometry ratio Cr2+:CO is 1:1 [33,36]. The catalysts can be classified in decreasing order of Cr2+ (CrA 2+ and CrB 2+) species: 1CrDSi>1CrASi⪢1CrCSi>1CrBSi, owing to its CO chemisorption results. These results are also related to the percentage of Cr3+, obtained in previous TPR and DRS analyses, and in the complete reduction of the Cr6+ present for Cr2+ [17]. The 1CrASi and 1CrDSi catalysts, that presented only Cr6+ after the calcination and total reduction to Cr2+, showed the highest values of CO chemisorption, presenting the largest fractions of Cr2+ active sites. The 1CrBSi and 1CrCSi catalysts presented the lowest amount of CO, also in agreement with the smaller percentage of Cr6+ in the calcined state and, therefore, smaller amount of Cr2+ sites after reduction. The largest chemisorption of CO in the 1CrDSi catalyst compared with the 1CrASi is associated to the largest fraction of CrA 2++CrB 2+ active species than CrC 2+, that does not adsorb CO and it is not active in the polymerization. The 3CrSiP6 physical mixture presented low CO chemisorption in contrast with the 1CrDSi catalyst, that was also prepared with CrO3. However, the CO chemisorption of the physical mixture was similar to the obtained for the 1CrBSi catalyst, which presented smaller Cr2+ fraction. The lower CO chemisorption of the physical mixture can be ascribed to the largest fraction of CrC 2+. Therefore, the 1CrASi and 1CrDSi catalysts presented the largest CrA 2++CrB 2+ fractions. The 1CrBSi and 1CrCSi presented Cr2+ and Cr3+ species; this last one cannot be reduced by carbon monoxide and does not chemisorb CO. The fraction of CrA 2+ was greater than the fraction of CrB 2+ for all the samples. According to the literature [7], CrA 2+ is transformed into CrC 2+ at high temperatures under vacuum. This behavior is believed to be connected to the greater amount of CrB 2+ than CrA 2+ species for catalysts prepared with chromium acetate (1 and 3wt.% Cr) in our previous work [18]. For these samples, we used a higher evacuation temperature (773K) after reduction than in this work. Therefore, another important point is to compare the Cr2+ species distribution in the same treatment conditions. 3.2.2 Ethylene polymerization The catalysts presented activities in the ethylene polymerization related to the amount of CrA 2+ and CrB 2+ active sites (Table 5). A correlation is observed between these parameters, resulting in two groups of catalysts in according to its activities: 1CrDSi/1CrASi and 1CrBSi/1CrCSi. The activity of the CrA 2+ and CrB 2+ sites was similar, since samples with distinct CrA 2+/(CrA 2++CrB 2+) ratios, between 64 and 93%, and total of active sites similar (Table 5) presented comparable polymerization activities, 320 and 376kgPE/gCr2+ (1CrASi and 1CrDSi, respectively). Thus, the ethylene polymerization is proportional to the total amount of CrA 2+ and CrB 2+ sites and the activity of these species is equivalent, as observed in Fig. 11 . The CO chemisorption showed to be an important characterization technique to distinguish the Cr/SiO2 catalysts in order to evaluate the activity in the ethylene polymerization. The determination of the chromium species distribution and the activity of these species in the ethylene polymerization are very difficult due to the presence of distincts Cr2+ (of the types A, B and C) and of the Cr3+ species, which does not reduce and is inactive in the polymerization (Table 5). The difficult in obtaining the supported pure species of Cr2+ (CrA, CrB and CrC) as reference and the distinct characterization approaches hinder the results interpretations. Also contribute for the complexity of this system, the ease to oxidation of Cr2+ [34] and the change in the Cr2+ species distribution, due to distinct condition of preparation and pretreatment [7]. Besides, chromium catalysts for polymerization have total amount of metal around 1wt.% Cr. This low content makes difficult the quantification of chromium active sites. 4 Conclusions The selectivity of the O2 and CO chemisorption to characterize the Cr2+ and amorphous Cr3+ sites, respectively, was verified. It was observed correlation between the O2 and CO chemisorptions and the activities for the dehydrogenation and polymerization reactions, respectively. Alumina disperses chromium particles in its surface better than silica. This phenomena is driven by the surface hydroxyls distribution and, probably, by the affinity between the crystallographic orientation of α-Cr2O3 and of the support. Physical mixtures of CrO3 with alumina present activity in the dehydrogenation in the same extent to the obtained with the catalysts, ascribed to a spontaneous spreading process of the chromium oxide(VI). The cyclohexane dehydrogenation reaction showed to be structure-sensitive for chromium catalysts. The activity was favored by the chromium particles agglomeration. The activity of the Cr/SiO2 catalysts to the ethylene polymerization is associated to the amount of CrA 2++CrB 2+ species. These chromium species present similar activities in the polymerization. coredata.dc:description: Chromium catalysts, prepared with different chromium contents, supports and precursor compounds, were characterized by O2 and CO chemisorption, in order to quantify the Cr3+ and Cr2+ sites, active species to dehydrogenation and ethylene polymerization reactions. Both probe molecules, O2 and CO, showed to be selective to the chromium active species, Cr3+ and Cr2+, respectively, and a valid method to quantify these sites. Distinct chromium species, Cr6+, amorphous Cr3+, crystalline Cr3+ and Cr2+, were characterized by XRD, DRS, TPR, FT-IR and DRIFTS in the calcined and reduced catalysts. The distribution of chromium species, which depends on the content, precursor compound and support, was related to the catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation and polymerization reactions. The catalytic activity to cyclohexane dehydrogenation depends on the dispersion of amorphous Cr3+ species. The activity in the ethylene polymerization is related to the amount of CrA 2+ and CrB 2+ species. Both sites showed similar activities.
